G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the **Boston Housing Court** pursuant to **G.L. c. 185C, § 3**, as the premises are located within the City of Boston and the cause of action arose therein.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under **G.L. c. 239**, **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, and **G.L. c. 231, § 1**, as the Plaintiff seeks damages for the Defendant’s breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, every landlord is obligated not to “directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 1.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under **G.L. c. 239**, **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, and **G.L. c. 231, § 1**, as the Plaintiff seeks damages for the Defendant’s breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

105 C.M.R. 410.500.proposition: After several weeks without repair, Plaintiff contacted the **City of Boston Inspectional Services Department**, which inspected the premises and cited violations of the state and city housing codes, including water infiltration and dampness in violation of **105 C.M.R. 410.500** and **G.L. c. 111, § 127A**.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: After several weeks without repair, Plaintiff contacted the **City of Boston Inspectional Services Department**, which inspected the premises and cited violations of the state and city housing codes, including water infiltration and dampness in violation of **105 C.M.R. 410.500** and **G.L. c. 111, § 127A**.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is violated when a landlord, by act or omission, allows conditions to persist that cause the tenant substantial interference with the use of the premises. See **Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); **Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord breaches the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, giving rise to constructive eviction, where substantial interference with the premises is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done, and where the landlord had the ability to control the condition but did not effectively remedy it. The court emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling and affirms judgments for tenants who suffered substantial interference from noise the landlords allowed to persist. This directly matches the proposition about violation of quiet enjoyment by act or omission allowing substantial interference to continue.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: "There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable."

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is violated when a landlord, by act or omission, allows conditions to persist that cause the tenant substantial interference with the use of the premises. See **Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); **Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat, a basic service, during the heating season “constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment,” and emphasizes that liability turns on the landlord’s conduct and the natural and probable consequences, not intent. This aligns with the proposition that the covenant is violated when the landlord, by act or omission, allows conditions (here, no heat) that substantially interfere with the tenant’s use of the premises. The court applies G.L. c. 186, § 14 on exactly this basis.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Landlords are liable for constructive interference resulting from their failure to correct defective conditions.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to maintain habitable and sanitary conditions—here, by not fixing a porous wall that allowed repeated flooding—can create liability for interference with quiet enjoyment and related statutory remedies. The opinion explains that under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord is liable where its conduct (including omissions) that violate its duty to maintain sanitary conditions foreseeably interferes with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, even absent intent. This is effectively constructive interference arising from failure to correct defective conditions.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt:
The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443 (1979); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973). The jury found in answer to a special question... that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.
...
Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Persistent water leakage and dampness have been held to breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion does address breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but only in the context of criminal drug activity and lack of security measures, not water leakage or dampness. Nowhere does the court discuss water intrusion or similar physical conditions as constituting a breach of quiet enjoyment, so the case cannot be used as authority for that specific proposition.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: "We conclude that the judge erred in granting summary judgment for the defendant on the plaintiffs’ claim of violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14... We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures... to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment."

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Defendant’s inaction after repeated notice constitutes a **continuing breach**, see **Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion does not use the phrase “continuing breach,” but it expressly recognizes that a landlord’s failure to act after notice and repeated tenant complaints can constitute a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. In explaining prior precedent (Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.), the court characterizes the landlord as having “stood idle, despite continued requests and complaints,” and cites that scenario as an example of actionable conduct under § 14. Thus, the case supports the general principle that inaction after repeated notice can amount to a breach, though the ‘continuing breach’ label is not used explicitly.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Indeed, in each case since the 1973 statutory revision in which we have recognized a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, there was evidence that the landlord failed to act reasonably in the circumstances concerning a problem known to the landlord, and the natural and probable consequences of such failure caused the interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises. See, e.g., Cruz, supra at 790; Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285-288 (1994)… In Doe… we vacated the summary judgment… because ‘the record suggests that the [landlord] stood idle, despite continued requests and complaints by the tenants…’”}

Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151 (1985).proposition: **Leardi v. Brown**, 394 Mass. 151 (1985) — Tenant entitled to statutory damages for breach of rights under c. 186, § 14.
Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151 (1985).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses G.L. c. 186, § 14 only in connection with plaintiff Allisan’s individual quiet enjoyment claim and affirms a defense verdict, expressly requiring a substantial/serious interference and finding that standard not met. The court does not award, recognize, or describe any entitlement to statutory damages under c. 186, § 14; the only statutory damages awarded in the case are under G.L. c. 93A. Thus, Leardi v. Brown does not support the proposition that a tenant is entitled to statutory damages for a breach of rights under c. 186, § 14.
Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151 (1985).relevant_excerpt: “Allisan joined the class action as a named plaintiff, and brought individual claims on the basis of interference with quiet enjoyment of the premises in violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, and intentional infliction of emotional distress. The claims were tried, and on December 29, 1982, the judge of the Housing Court found in favor of the defendants… The judgment for the defendants as to the individual claims of Allisan is affirmed.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: **Haddad v. Gonzalez**, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) — Landlord liable for interference even absent physical eviction.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion is primarily about c. 93A damages for emotional distress, retaliation, warranty of habitability, and recusal. While the facts describe harassment and severe habitability defects, the court does not analyze or hold that a landlord is liable for interference with a tenant’s rights absent physical eviction, nor does it elaborate on liability under the covenant of quiet enjoyment or constructive eviction doctrines. The covenant of quiet enjoyment counterclaim is mentioned only in the procedural background and not discussed as a basis for the holding, so the case does not stand as authority for the stated proposition.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: “After a trial, a judge of the Housing Court found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims and awarded her damages under c. 186, treble damages under c. 93A (for the intentional infliction of emotional distress and violation of the warranty of habitability), and attorneys' fees and costs. … Based on the findings, as summarized above, the judge found in favor of Gonzalez on each of her counterclaims. To avoid awarding cumulative damages, however, the judge dismissed all but the retaliation and c. 93A counterclaims.”

Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.proposition: Pursuant to **Mass. R. Civ. P. 38**, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
